name: Kepler conjecture
rephrased: The Kepler conjecture states that the maximum average density achievable by packing identical spheres in three-dimensional space is approximately 74.05%, which is the density found in face-centered cubic and hexagonal close packing arrangements.
implication_form: If spheres of equal size are packed in three-dimensional Euclidean space, then the average density cannot exceed that of face-centered cubic or hexagonal close packing arrangements.
explained: The Kepler conjecture states that the maximum density achievable in a packing of identical spheres in three-dimensional Euclidean space is π / √18 ≈ 0.74048049123, which is the density achieved by both the face-centered cubic (FCC) and hexagonal close-packed (HCP) arrangements. This means that no arrangement of spheres can achieve a higher average density than these close-packed structures.
